importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The shutdown began on this date, marking the start of the current fiscal impasse over federal funding.
The Pentagon announced it would cover military pay for this date, preventing active-duty personnel from going unpaid.
The article was updated on this date, reflecting the ongoing status and evolving details of the shutdown's impact.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown spans the current fiscal year, with no end in sight and ongoing debate over funding and pay.

keyTakeAways: Federal workers are going unpaid during the shutdown, with over 730,000 furloughed and roughly 670,000 working without pay, while only 830,000 are being paid due to reliance on non-annual appropriations.

Lawmakers, Supreme Court justices, federal judges, political appointees, and certain essential federal employees continue to receive pay due to constitutional provisions or alternative funding sources.

President Donald Trump is shielding military personnel and specific law enforcement agencies (including 70,000 DHS staff) from pay cuts using Pentagon R&D funds and executive actions, despite threatening broader back pay violations.
The White House is considering a new interpretation of the 2019 law on back pay, arguing it does not apply to furloughed employees, undermining financial protections for millions of federal workers.
Federal contractors — such as security and office support staff — face job losses with no guarantee of compensation or back pay at the end of the shutdown.
Many federal employees are living paycheck to paycheck, with financial hardship leading to fears of losing homes, cars, or being unable to feed their families.

Senate GOP leaders propose a bill to pay certain essential workers, but Democrats oppose it unless it applies to all non-paid federal employees, highlighting partisan divide over fairness and shutdown resolution.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head of the executive branch, central figure in decisions about pay during the shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is actively shielding certain federal workers and military personnel from pay cuts, and pushing a controversial interpretation of back pay laws to avoid paying furloughed employees.

namedEntities.name: Senate GOP leaders
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political leaders within the Senate Republican Party
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are proposing a bill to pay essential federal workers during the shutdown, though with conditions that may not satisfy Democratic opposition.

namedEntities.name: Kristi Noem
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She announced that 70,000 DHS law enforcement personnel will receive pay during the shutdown, indicating targeted federal employee protection.

namedEntities.name: Supreme Court justices
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Judicial officers in the federal judiciary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They continue receiving pay due to constitutional provisions, highlighting a key distinction between judicial and other federal employees.

namedEntities.name: Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) special agents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration has committed to paying FBI special agents, reflecting a targeted exception to the shutdown pay cuts.

namedEntities.name: Department of Homeland Security (DHS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal executive agency responsible for national security and immigration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It includes law enforcement units that are being paid during the shutdown, showing targeted federal workforce protections.

namedEntities.name: Military (active-duty and reserve members)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are temporarily protected from pay cuts by $8 billion in Pentagon R&D funds, though only for the October 15 payroll.

namedEntities.name: Bipartisan Policy Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provided data on which federal workers are being paid or furloughed, offering a credible analysis of the shutdown’s scope and impact.

namedEntities.name: 2019 Back Pay Law
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal legislation ensuring pay for furloughed employees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House is challenging its applicability to furloughed employees, raising legal and ethical concerns about worker protection.

namedEntities.name: One Big Beautiful Bill Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides alternative funding that allows some federal workers to remain paid during shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Inflation Reduction Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Used as a funding source to pay some federal workers, such as IRS staff, though later revised to furlough half its workforce.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the ongoing federal government shutdown beginning October 1, 2025, over 1.5 million federal employees are either furloughed or working without pay, while lawmakers, judges, and certain essential personnel continue to receive pay due to constitutional or alternative funding provisions. President Donald Trump has taken steps to protect military personnel and specific law enforcement staff, including 70,000 DHS employees and FBI agents, using Pentagon funds. However, the White House is challenging the 2019 back pay law to avoid paying furloughed employees, sparking debate over fairness and constitutional obligations. The shutdown disproportionately impacts low-income federal workers, many of whom face severe financial hardship, including risks of losing homes or food. Senate GOP leaders propose a bill to pay essential workers, but Democrats oppose it unless it applies universally, signaling a deep partisan divide on how to resolve the crisis. The article highlights both the constitutional protections for certain federal officials and the growing human cost of political gridlock.
title: Here’s who gets paid — and who doesn’t — during a federal government shutdown
